headline: US FTC will require Synopsys, Ansys to divest certain assets to resolve merger concerns
summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. Federal Trade Commission said on Wednesday it will require two software companies —Synopsys and Ansys— to divest certain assets to resolve antitrust concerns surrounding their $35 billion merger.  The proposed divestiture will preserve competition across several software tool markets that are critical for the design of semiconductors and light simulation devices, according to the commission.  Synopsys is a leading developer and supplier used to design semiconductors, while Ansys provides simulation software tools used for testing products including semiconductors.

raw.headline: US FTC will require Synopsys, Ansys to divest certain assets to resolve merger concerns
raw.summary: WASHINGTON (Reuters) -The U.S. Federal Trade Commission said on Wednesday it will require two software companies —Synopsys and Ansys— to divest certain assets to resolve antitrust concerns surrounding their $35 billion merger.  The proposed divestiture will preserve competition across several software tool markets that are critical for the design of semiconductors and light simulation devices, according to the commission.  Synopsys is a leading developer and supplier used to design semiconductors, while Ansys provides simulation software tools used for testing products including semiconductors.

headline: Synopsys Says It Hasn’t Received Notice to Stop Exports to China, Pushing Back on Report
summary: Shares of semiconductor software design companies  Synopsys  and  Cadence Design Systems  were bouncing back in late trading Wednesday after Synopsys pushed back on a report that it had been told by the Trump administration to stop sales to China.  On Wednesday afternoon, the Financial Times had cited people familiar with the matter who said that the Commerce Department told electronic design automation companies like Cadence and Synopsys to stop supplying their technology to China.  “We are aware of the reporting and speculation, but Synopsys has not received a notice from BIS.”

raw.headline: Synopsys Says It Hasn’t Received Notice to Stop Exports to China, Pushing Back on Report

On Wednesday afternoon, the Financial Times had cited people familiar with the matter who said that the Commerce Department told electronic design automation companies like Cadence and Synopsys to stop supplying their technology to China.  “We are aware of the reporting and speculation, but Synopsys has not received a notice from BIS.”

headline: Why Synopsis Stock Fell Today
summary: The Trump administration has ordered Synopsis to stop doing business with Chinese chip companies.  Shares of Synopsys (NASDAQ: SNPS) fell on Wednesday.  The move down came as the S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC) lost 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite (NASDAQINDEX: ^IXIC) lost 0.6%.

headline: Synopsys: Fiscal Q2 Earnings Snapshot
summary: The average estimate of seven analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of $3.39 per share. The maker of software used to test and develop chips posted revenue of $1.6 billion in the period, which matched Street forecasts. For the current quarter ending in July, Synopsys expects its per-share earnings to range from $3.82 to $3.87.

headline: Synopsys forecasts quarterly revenue largely above estimates
summary: Shares of the company rose 3.8% in extended trading, after falling about 10% during the session following a media report that said the Trump administration had ordered U.S. chip design software firms to cease sales to Chinese groups.  Synopsys CEO Sassine Ghazi said on a post-earnings call that the company had not received a letter from the U.S. Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS), which enforces export controls.

headline: Synopsys Posts Financial Results for Second Quarter Fiscal Year 2025
summary: Synopsys, Inc. (Nasdaq: SNPS) today reported results for its second quarter of fiscal year 2025. Revenue for the second quarter of fiscal year 2025 was $1.604 billion, compared to $1.455 billion for the second quarter of fiscal year 2024.

headline: Trump orders U.S. firms to halt chip software sales to China, says FT
summary: Investing.com -- In a new move to hinder China’s development of advanced semiconductor chips, the Trump administration has reportedly instructed U.S. companies that provide software used in semiconductor design to cease sales to Chinese entities, according to a report by the Financial Times on Wednesday. The directive was issued by the Bureau of Industry and Security, a division of the U.S. commerce department that supervises export controls.

raw.headline: Trump orders U.S. firms to halt chip software sales to China, says FT

The directive was issued by the Bureau of Industry and Security, a division of the U.S. commerce department that supervises export controls.

headline: US chip designers ordered by Trump to stop selling to China: FT
summary: US companies that create software to help design chips, such as Synopsys (SNPS) and Cadence Design Systems (CDNS), have been ordered by the Commerce Department to stop selling their services to China, according to a report from the Financial Times. Market Domination Anchors Julie Hyman and Josh Lipton report the details in the video above.
